In this big screen adaptation of the classic TV series, a doctor is falsely convicted of murdering his wife, but escapes en route to prison. This is an entertaining, fast-moving adventure yarn with non-stop action. In fact, there is perhaps a bit too much action, as it starts to run out of steam towards the end. The story is fairly straightforward but tends to ramble and becomes somewhat muddled in the latter stages. It could have benefited from tighter editing. Ford is well cast in the title role, but Jones steals the film in his Oscar winning role as the U.S. Marshal who doggedly pursues him. It's mindless fun, with little attempt at plausibility in the plot.

Yeah, I remember watching this film a while ago, but honestly it really didn't impress me. I guess it had a lot to do with most of the action occurring within the first half hour, and the rest of it simply being a man hunt, and a detective story. Of course, like a lot of films, there are a lot of inconsistencies, and then there is also the issue of certain things happening in the film that wouldn't happen in real life - such as Kimble being interviewed by the police without a lawyer. In fact, the whole trial was just so unrealistic that I sort of wonder how he was convicted in the first place.Anyway, the film is about this guy named Richard Kimble who returns home to discover that a one armed man is in the process of killing his wife. He attempts to stop him, but to no avail, and upon calling the police he is arrested and charged with murder. As I mentioned, he is also convicted and sent onto death row. However, on the way to the prison there is an attempted escape, and the bus crashes enabling him to flee. Then this US marshal comes along and attempts to track him down while Kimble is attempting to get to the bottom of the mystery.It's a fun movie, but as I mentioned there are an awful lot of flaws in it. Like, they seem to spend most of the time attempting to track Kimble down, and no time tracking down any of the other escapees. Then again, that probably does have something to do with the movie being focused primarily on him, and not on any of the other escaped convicts. Then there is the fact that he jumps off of a dam and into a river, however they seem to assume that he survived, when it is highly likely that a jump from that height would've killed him. Then again, it is a Hollywood movie so I guess we do have to take that into account.In the end though, while it is a fun film, it sort of does dry up pretty quickly, especially when it settles into Kimble attempting to clear his name. Mind you, I also find that somewhat problematic as well considering that there is also the issue of the fact that he escaped from lawful custody. Yeah, that's going to create a bit of a problem because it seems that nobody is interested in clearing his name, and the only way that he can clear his name is by escaping from lawful custody.Yeah, there are certainly quite a few issues that I had with the film, but it still is pretty popular, at least among the people that I know. On the other hand, I guess it is the case with a lot of other Hollywood movies - we really have to take reality with a grain of salt and basically just go with the flow and enjoy the ride. It was just that the ride with this film wasn't actually as good as some others that I have watched. Hey, at least I got an opportunity to watch it again because I probably wouldn't have otherwise.

Review title: Remembered It As Memorable...But Now Realize It Hasn't Aged As Well As I Thought
Review_body: When I first watched "The Fugitive" as a teenager, I remember thinking how great of a movie it was at the time. Having not seen it for a number of years, though, a repeat viewing recently showed me that it wasn't the classic that I remembered.For a basic plot summary, this movie tells the story of Richard Kimball (Harrison Ford), a man falsely convicted of murdering his wife. He claims that a one-armed attacker inside his home was the real culprit. During a prisoner transfer, Kimball manages to escape his custody and begin the search for the one-armed man. Hot on his heels, though, is U.S. Marshal Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones)."The Fugitive" is not a bad movie by any stretch of the imagination. It has a decent plot, some decent adventure, and some good actors. Yet, that is part of the problem...there are too many flaws for the entire experience to ever crest that "decent" mark.It is clear that this movie was made as a star vehicle for Ford and little more. His performance is solid as Kimball, but even then his character is not given enough real meaty scenes/dialogue to stand out. We needed to know more about Kimball's past and his relationship with his now- deceased spouse in order to truly care.Two other things in this movie really bugged me:1. The whole experience could have been much more of an intriguing mystery had the producers/writers left some doubt as to what actually happened to Mrs. Kimball. Instead, it is clear early one that Ford's character is telling the truth.2. For me, at least, what kept me watching for most of the movie was that anticipated moment where Kimball would find the one-armed man and the showdown would commence. I won't completely ruin the ending for you, but suffice it to say that it is more than a bit of a letdown.Overall, then, I put "The Fugitive" about on par with another Ford film, "Witness". Both movies are decent at what they do (so three stars), but neither pushes itself onto that "next level".

Coming from a hit television series, this film tells of Dr. Richard Kimble's quest for the truth behind the murder of his wife, a crime for which he is accused. The film is a classic police thriller, with an innocent running away from a police officer who pulls his booties to pick him up. The thrill of the film lies in this game of cat and mouse and the mystery surrounding an unresolved crime. Harrison Ford gives life to the doctor trapped in this trap, while Tommy Lee Jones is the investigator whose mission is to catch him. Both actors are at their best and both are able to do a masterful job in this film at what they have done best to this day. There are no great special or visual effects. This film is worth the story that counts and the talent of its central actors. And that was definitely a good bet.

I expected a dull action movie and in fact, it's rather good. First, the choice of the Chicago region is cool as it mixes the nature and an authentic city, traits that can't afford NYC (no nature) or LA (no city). Next, Harrison is always excellent playing an overtaken but pugnacious doctor (see « frantic », « what lies ») and Jones brings a surprising but cool side to a unpleasant job. Sure, the story has a lot of improbabilities (why didn't Harrison manage to prove his innocence at the trial for example) and the last sequence in the hotel is a bit boring. But the idea of this running innocent man is really punchy and it's easy to understand why it was a TV show at the beginning.

Review title: In A Word? Solid! In Two Words? Edgy & Enjoyable!

I've seen "The Fugitive" dozens of times over the years, and it's one of the most enduring and intelligent thrillers ever made. Like any thriller by director William Friedkin, it's basically one long chase that never pauses or lets you take a breather; it's that exhausting an experience to watch "The Fugitive." And it has the performances to boot. Based on the television series, Harrison Ford is Dr. Richard Kimble, a respected Chicago surgeon who is wrongfully accused of brutally murdering his wife (Sela Ward). Sentenced to die by lethal injection by the courts, fate and an attempted jail break (culminating in one of the most exciting action sequences in the film) spring Richard free, and place him on the run for his life as he searches for the real killer. The killer in this case, a one-armed man, is the obsession of the good doctor as he dawns disguises and tries to stay one step ahead of dogged F.B.I. marshal Sam Gerard (Best Supporting Actor Oscar-winner Tommy Lee Jones) and his team of law enforcement officers. And the chase is on. As the picture roles, we're in the action with two men who are both chasing after radically different goals; it's the hunter and the hunted. We're with Ford's desperate doctor as he searches vigorously for a fiendish murderer, and we're with Jones' agent as he tracks Kimble's trail. Andrew Davis ("Under Siege") directs the film's frequent chase sequences with intense focus that is reminiscent of what we've become used to in Friedkin's action films. It's really exciting stuff here.10/10

Review title: Snappy, Up-Tempo Action with a Decidedly '90s Aesthetic
Review_body: Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones race around in circles for this memorable early '90s cat-and-mouse blockbuster, skillfully adapting and modernizing a four-season television series from thirty years prior. The Fugitive doesn't fool around, racing through dozens of heavy plot points in the first hour without feeling overwhelming or hyperactive. It's a succinct, condensed version of a once-sprawling serial, one which trims away the obligatory TV padding without skipping any good bits.While it's trucking through those establishing shots, the story is a whiplash stunner; in the blink of an eye, we see our protagonist as a respected physician, grieving husband, bewildered murder suspect, sentenced convict, opportunistic escapee and outdoor survivalist, with one particularly well-executed train derailment thrown in to really kick off all the turmoil. Almost by necessity, the second act slows down to focus on the chase, balancing Ford's attempts to lay low with Jones's top-of-the-food-chain detective work. That performs well, too, a firm gear-shift from the opening salvo's manic mayhem (one that's certainly assisted by its two phenomenal cornerstone stars), though it does lose its way as all the different points converge and the moment of resolution draws near. By contrast, the ending falls more on the bland, derivative side; careful suspense cast aside in favor of a big chair-tossing, pipe-swinging, rock'em'sock'em finale. These scenes are inoffensive, but a decided step down from what we'd seen and felt just prior. Put it this way: I still vividly recalled the bus crash and dam jump, decades after I last saw them. I'd forgotten all about the climactic rooftop fist fight.While the gettin's good, it's real good. A fairly simple premise with plenty of intrigue and gray morality, a tight script, more than one all-decade action set, a super-sized portion of Tommy Lee Jones intensity and lots and lots of chances for grim Harrison Ford to glance worriedly over his shoulder. Maybe not perfect, but it still holds up.

Review title: Excellent, influential big-screen treatment of an old TV show.
Review_body: Nowadays it seems that every other month there is a big-screen release adapted from an old TV show. Think about it.... they've virtually all be done: Lost In Space, The Avengers, Starsky & Hutch, The Saint, Charlie's Angels, Fantastic Four, Mission: Impossible and Thuderbirds to name but a few, with more promised for the future (at the time I'm writing this, big-screen treatments of The A-Team and The Persuaders are on the cards). The trend for borrowing TV concepts and transforming them into major film releases really began with this 1993 offering. Knowledgeable film buffs might argue that Batman or even Flash Gordon pre-date The Fugitive and were also TV shows long, long ago, but both of those films actually drew their inspiration more from the original comic books than their television ancestors. Therefore, The Fugitive is probably the first genuine cinematic version of an old TV show. Ironically, after all the years since its release, it is still the best of the bunch too!Dr Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford) returns home one night to find his wife bleeding to death and a burglar in his house. He fights with the burglar, and discovers that his assailant actually has a prosthetic arm, before finally being overwhelmed. When the police arrive, they refuse to believe that Kimble's wife was murdered by an intruder and instead charge Kimble himself with the crime. He is convicted and put on Death Row. However, Kimble gets an unexpected chance to clear his name when the bus transporting him to jail crashes off the road and ends up straddling a railway line. Kimble makes a breathtaking escape from the crippled vehicle and goes on the run in the neighbouring woodland. Ace FBI agent Sam Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones) is brought in to track down the fugitive and the two of them are soon locked in a battle of wills, which ends when Kimble makes a remarkable escape from his pursuers in a storm drain. Later, Kimble makes his way to Chicago where he begins to piece together the mystery of his wife's murder, eventually realising that he was set up to divert attention from a conspiracy in the medical world.Ford is terrific as the titular fugitive and he gets superb support from Jones as the Federal Marshal on his tail (the latter got an Oscar for his efforts). The film is brilliantly scripted by Jeb Stuart and David Twohy, who manage to remain faithful to the plot of the original show, while updating it for contemporary audiences and condensing it into a 2 hour narrative. James Newton Howard also does a fabulous job with his score, which is emotional and exciting at all the right moments. The story is paced very thoughtfully, so that the characters are introduced and developed meaningfully, without tedium setting in while the viewers await the action. The Fugitive is a terrific film, totally absorbing and exciting from beginning to end, and easily one of the films of its year.

Review title: Excellent, nail-biting, edge-of-your-seat action movie that you'll want to see over and over again
Review_body: THE FUGITIVE, in my opinion, is an excellent, nail-biting, edge-of-your-seat action movie that you'll want to see over and over again. One of the supreme examples of '90s crime action flicks also represents the best of another kind of '90s movie, the TV series remake. "The Fugitive" takes its name, although not so much of its content, from the 1963-67 TV series that starred David Janssen as Dr. Richard Kimble, wrongly convicted of killing his wife, on the lam, and on the trail of a one-armed killer.That's all in the movie, too, with the exception that Harrison Ford now plays Kimble. But since the movie doesn't have the luxury of four seasons worth of hour-long episodes to stretch out the denouement, things are much faster-paced. Just how much faster-paced is established in the opening credit sequence, which shows Kimble arrested, tried, convicted, and escaping a stranded prison bus just ahead of a speeding train in one of moviedom's all-time-best cliffhangers.Director Andrew Davis has had much success with two kinds of movies, those set in Chicago and those featuring Tommy Lee Jones. This has both, so it makes sense that it is Davis's career moment, and Jones' one Oscar-winning performance. Davis's feeling for the Windy City, the grittiness of the backstreets and the skyscrapers lit up like Christmas trees at night, creates a compelling composition. He also populates his film with vivid, authentic-looking characters, like the boarding-house lady and her son, the roller-blading hospital attendant, and the surly CPD detectives, some of whom are welcomely recognizable from Davis's earlier, excellent Chuck Norris vehicle, "Code Of Silence."People are quick to credit Jones for his performance, and he deserved Academy consideration, playing against the Javert formula and walking a tightrope as he alternates between ruthless and determined on the one hand, and amiable and goofy on the other, sometimes in the same scene. His lines aren't that witty or cool, but Jones' delivery of simple lines like "I don't care," "I don't bargain," "We got a gopher," and "The big dog's always right" makes all the difference. The interplay between Jones and his supporting cast of underlings has an engaging yet professional-seeming vibe that draws you in.But Jones' performance wouldn't shine so brightly if he were chasing an actor like Adam Sandler or Howie Long. Harrison Ford really emotes in this film, creating an emotional bond with the audience that keeps him at the center of our attentions no matter how bright and pleasing Jones' pyrotechnics get to be. Ford's breakdown scene during the police interrogation is riveting, nakedly emotional, and all the more surprising because, according to the DVD commentary, it was improvised. Throughout the rest of his performance, Ford dispenses with the glamour shots and lets us in on his character's grasping desperation, whether he's looking through files, making a phony ID, licking egg off his fingers, or shaving his beard. The result is a suspense film that really works because it draws you into feelings so real they hurt.In addition to being a good acting primer, "The Fugitive" also boasts a top-flight clinic on editing. This is apparent not only with the train escape scene and Kimble's other narrow misses, but the fact we are distracted from some obvious plot holes. I won't go into the problematic reveal of the real culprits, except that they would seem unlikely to have been overlooked by the police or by Kimble in any actual investigation worth its salt. The pharmaceutical angle is a weak MacGuffin, not really explaining the whys of the crime. But when you see those flashbacks of the gorgeous Sela Ward dropping rose petals behind her while the killer waits to strike, logic flaws kind of go out the window, at least the first time around.A great film about justice, that works all the better because it plays with the conventions of the form. Who says there's never anything good on TV?

Based upon the popular television series of the mid 60's, this thriller converts well to the big screen thanks to some competent direction from Andrew Davis, and two sure-footed performances from the lead stars.Harrison Ford adds yet another character to his already impressive collection as Dr. Richard Kimble, a man who, whilst on the run, searches for the one-armed man he claims killed his wife. And Tommy Lee Jones continues to grow in stature, after his Oscar nominated performance in "J.F.K.", with a very good turn as Deputy Gerard, the man pursuing Kimble.Davis develops tension early and maintains it well, right up until the suitable, though none too surprising, ending. Plot complexities near the finish may lose some viewers, but most of the audience will enjoy every minute. James Newton Howard's score is effective.Sunday, October 3, 1993 - Croydon Twin Cinema

A smart, compelling, and very well-acted thriller, The Fugitive is one hell of an entertaining ride, and quite possibly some of Harrison Ford's best work. The film is entertaining from start to finish, and though it may not be edge of your seat entertainment for some of its long runtime, it is more than capable to gain your attention, and fill you with just enough interest and suspense to make for one very enjoyable time. Harrison Ford is fantastic in his role as Dr. Richard Kimble, and is my favorite performance I have seen of him so far throughout the films I have seen of his career. Tommy Lee Jones also provides for a terrific performance, and all other actors involved also give it their best, but none are as memorable as the two leads. The film is cleverly paced, although it can be a bit choppy at its beginning remarks. However, The Fugitive is able to make up for this by providing a truly compelling tale of innocence and crime on a scale I have not seen before. The writing is quite good, as well as the soundtrack, and its cinematography quite fine as well. In the end, The Fugitive has a few minor issues, but is mostly a very enjoyable and classic thriller work that is bound to be a classic in due time.

Review title: A Mystery Masterpiece in Every Sense of the Word!
Review_body: Andrew Davis is an action director who has done a few decent films, but one great. This is a mystery/thriller with a brain that has it all. Car chases, foot chases, one-versus-all, and a complex plot enhance a generic whodunit into new heights and into the highest realm of movie magic.I have never seen the TV show this is based upon, but I don't care. This movie is good enough for me (and probably better too). Harrison Ford give his greatest performance as well-respected Chicago physician Richard Kimble. The first few minutes of the film document his conviction of the murder of his wife. It alternates in such a creative and exciting way to see exactly what we're dealing with: Kimble's wife is murdered by a one- armed man and the evidence against the innocent Richard is high. The way that this is shown is just perfect. It is well created and is makes the viewer feel slightly uncomfortable and shocked, but thirsting for more. On the bus to be incarcerated, it crashes, leaving Kimble to go on the run from the entire country. Nobody is on his side and justice has not been brought, but we want Kimble to survive and the bad guys brought down. That's a reason why I love this so much, a regular man faced with certain death must put the wrong things right with impossible odds and lots on the line.Richard's first goal in the manhunt is to change his appearance. His change makes him look like the Harrison Ford we all know. After he changes his look, he is able to waltz right by some of the key people that are trying to kill him. That is where the brains come. He can dodge his enemies at ease in such a calm but brilliant way. That causes his evasion to become easier and he can focus on who killed his wife and why. Meanwhile, a tough team of US Marshals, led by Sam Gerard (Jones), lead the way for the hunt of Dr. Kimble. The intro of Gerard and his crew is where the friction really heats up. As Kimble digs deep into the case, so does Gerard and his men in a parallel fashion. Eventually, Gerard has a change of heart and the Marshals soon become on the same side as Kimble. Kimble's discoveries in the murder are shocking and need full attention and thinking. Movies like these are the best. Loyalties change hands and secrets are revealed that will make the viewers' blood boil. I don't want to ruin anything about the conspiracy behind the murder, but it is sharp to perfection.Think to yourself what makes a movie great, truly. The Fugitive has those. Now think about what makes a mystery great, truly. The Fugitive has those. The first little bit is an exciting manhunt that feels like one man against the world. While keeping the manhunt premise, it subtly shifts gears into more of a whodunit. There are so many people linked to the murder and the movie cleverly teases them into the picture, raising excitement. The bar constantly raises, so the way it all comes together must be something very smart. And it is! The characters are so well-written and acted with Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones shining as the crown jewels.4/4

The first hour of "The Fugitive" is just fantastic. It's one of the most brilliant cat-and-mouse games I've ever seen, well-acted and extremely gripping. The reason it works is probably because there isn't that much of a story to deal with at that point, it's just one guy running and everyone else trying to catch him. The first act also gives us that one scene from "The Fugitive" literally everyone knows: the immortal dam scene. It just gets better every time I watch it, even the super-obvious dummy can't ruin it. Sadly the movie kinda sinks in after that, probably because from then on more and more people start to sympathize with Harrison Ford's character. When he was hated and chased down like an animal the movie was chock-full of tension, but in the second half they barely even seem to want to find him and it's tough to keep interest. There's a detective story woven in, but this storyline is just so pedestrian and breaks the claustrophobic mood. There is no real threat anymore, you don't fear for the main character's well-being, and this leads to a rather predictable finale that even the brilliant Jeroen Krabbé couldn't save. I get why this movie is such a classic, because the greatness of some scenes is tough to deny, but as a whole it's not really that superb.

Review title: Good acting and directing, constant action and tension. Even after many years this movie still stands
Review_body: "The Fugitive" is one of those movies that you may already have seen a dozen of times, but which still seems to surprise every time that you watch it. I don't know what it actually is that makes this movie so good, but it sure works. It's probably the combination of a good script, good acting and the abundance of action that's always present, but never exaggerated.The movie is about a doctor who's wife has been murdered by a one-armed man. He's innocent but is accused of the murder and convicted by court. He will get a lethal injection soon, but as he is transfered to another jail, the bus in which he is transported with some other inmates, crashes. He knows to escape and is determined to find his wife's murderer, but has to try to stay out of the hands of the police. The result is an interesting cat-and-mouse game between him and the police that never allows your attention to fade away.The story is perhaps not exceptional, but thanks to the good directing and acting and the constant action and tension, this movie really delivers everything that you can expect from it. I give it an 8.5 - 9/10.

Review title: A murdered wife. A one-armed man. An obsessed detective. The chase begins.
Review_body: A well respected Chicago surgeon Dr. Richard Kimble has found out that his wife, Helen, has been murdered ferociously in her own home. The police found Kimble and accused him of the murder. Then, Kimble was tried, convicted, and sentenced to death. However, on the way to prison, Kimble's transport crashed. Kimble escapes and is now on the run. Deputy Samuel Gerard from Chicago takes charge of the chase of Kimble. Meanwhile, Kimble makes up his own investigation to find who really killed his life, and to lure Gerard and his team into it as well.I loved this movie. I really liked it a lot. Compared to other chase films, this is one of the best. This movie is based off a TV series and no, I did not see it. However, I was really convinced that the events that happened in the film could happen in real life. It's realistic. This film is taught and intelligent. In fact, you find out who killed the protagonist's wife way early into the movie and does not play like a "whodunnit" film.However, the whole explanation in the end is a let-down, no doubt. In fact, the movie stretches a bit. The whole final act plays unlike anything from the the first two acts. I felt that the movie needed to end a bit earlier and the action in the end was going a bit too long and too far. Another thing I was annoyed with in here was the false or trick scenes, where something you think will happen but because it's a movie, something else happens. It's really clichéd, I think.The performance by Harrison Ford was great. Tommy Lee Jones provides all the one liners here, which are more or less funny from other action movies. The action scenes in here are decent and sometimes great. Overall, it's a really good chase film, although it does fall short in the whole resolution and explanation.

One of the best (if not the very best) of the TV show adaptation movies. Not only is the film consistent with the theme of the series, but it juices it up with intense action and an involving, well-constructed plot.The movie adopts just enough of the popular '60's program's original elements, and blends them nicely with the right measure of new plot twists to concoct one furious and exciting ride. Harrison Ford takes the role magnificently originated by David Jansen, and puts his unique stamp on it to make a Dr. Richard Kimble that is his own. His perfect sparring partner is Marshall Sam Girard (Tommy Lee Jones), who takes Kimbles's escape as a personal challenge to a chess game of wits.Parallel cat-and-mouse duels are the stuff of this chess game: Kimble is not only the pursued, but also the pursuer of his own prey, the mysterious one-armed-man he saw fleeing from the murder scene. The action is constant, featuring leaps from dams, high speed ambulances, chases through sewers, fights, shootings, and more as each closes in. The train wreck sequence that sets Kimble on his trek to clear his name is one of the finest sequences ever filmed. The cast is exceptional. Never a dull moment from start to finish. A great mystery, and a great pursuit suspense thriller. This is the kind of movie that remains fun after multiple viewings. A keeper for sure.

This is a fine vehicle for Harrison Ford made even more agreeable by a clever, somewhat tongue in cheek performance by Tommy Lee Jones as a US Marshall out to have a good time getting the bad guy, even though the bad guy might not be so bad, and even though that's irrelevant, but hey, don't think so much and get me some coffee and a chocolate donut with those sprinkles on top, ya hear?This is also a Hollywood producer's orgasmic dream with a chase scene beginning in the first reel and lasting throughout. It is based on the 60s TV show of the same name, but gets its premise from a true crime story, that of Ohioan Dr. Sam Shepherd who actually went to jail for murdering his wife in the 50s. He too claimed to have fought off the real killer, but the forensic evidence and his personality were against him. Here we have Harrison Ford as the good doctor, and it doesn't take a Hollywood genius to tell you that the most popular leading man of the late twentieth century ain't about to play the kind of guy who murders his loving wife.Ford does a stand-up, competent job, saving lives and patting kids on the head as he plunges through sewers and off the top of a towering waterfall, steals an ambulance, survives a bullet wound and a bus wreck, etc. His fans will be pleased, but Tommy Lee Jones steals the show (and got a Best Supporting Oscar for his trouble) as a clever, wise-cracking good ole boy who has a lot of fun leading the posse. I wonder if he or director Andrew Davis invented the spin because without it, this wouldn't be half so good.This is not to be confused with, nor is it a remake of The Fugitive from 1947 starring Henry Fonda and directed by John Ford, a cinematic gem of an entirely different sort.See this for Tommy Lee Jones who has made a career out of turning oh-hum parts into something special.

Review title: A taut thriller with top notch performances from both Ford & Jones
Review_body: "The Fugitive" is based on the classic TV series of the same name that ran from 1963 to 1967. The finale of that series still ranks as one of the most watched episodes in U.S. history. So, while the TV show provided a promising template for a successful movie, it would nevertheless be a challenge to match the impact of the original.The story concerns Dr. Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford), a doctor falsely accused of killing his wife. Convicted of murder, a spectacular crash en route to prison allows him to escape and search for the real killer. Unfortunately for him, hard-nosed U.S. Marshall Samuel Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones) is determined to pursue his man until he's back in the hands of the authorities.The performances of Ford & Jones are the linchpins that hold the film together. Both characters are equally driven and the actors successfully bring this intensity to the screen. Their portrayals also have a depth not found in most action movies. Notably, Jones managed to snag both an Oscar and a Golden Globe for his work here. Apart from this pair, Joe Pantoliano & Julianne Moore make welcome appearances while the remainder of the cast is mostly composed of lesser-knowns who nevertheless perform admirably.Director Andrew Davis masterfully handled the film's action set-pieces along with the unravelling of the mystery at the core of the story. Even when the story gets a bit convoluted, the viewer is nevertheless propelled forward inexorably. The Oscar-nominated score by James Newton Howard is another important ingredient in the mix and is only one of several technical areas that received awards attention.Ultimately, "The Fugitive" lived up to its predecessor and became a huge commercial and critical success. A thrilling and engrossing action movie, it remains just as vital more than twenty years after its original release.

Review title: Excellent right the way through. (POSSIBLE SPOILERS.)
Review_body: Director Davis takes the blueprint for a (60's?) TV series and turns it into a multi-million dollar Hollywood blockbuster.  Like only a few of his directorial colleagues before him (De Palma is one) he succeeds.  "The Fugitive" is tremendously entertaining popcorn fare.   Star power is largely the key to this being such a compelling thriller. We have a protagonist and antagonist, as usual, but Jones as the antagonist doesn't overplay the character or make the audience hate him.  Ford is impressively humble as the doc on the run.   There is one outstanding setpiece, which I won't reveal (though most readers will probably already know what I'm referring to even if they haven't seen the film)   The script is not outstanding, but neither is it awful, just serviceable.  As the title implies, the majority of the movie follows Kimble as he is on the run from Gerrard.  This means that  all the best lines are given to Gerrard, and since he's not really the character we're meant to have invested our sympathies in, they just serve as comic relief.  The film rarely flags in pace, which must be attributed to Davis, but aside from that the direction is also merely serviceable.   The intensity of the flashback scenes is pleasing, and its important that the whole "one armed man" thing never feels like a subplot which detracts from the two main characters.  Watch it for the performances, and the perfect simplicity of the plot.  Who said great thrillers always have to be convoluted and spectacularly original?  Not me.

Review title: Love this film with more viewings{{SPOILERS MAybe?}}
Review_body: I saw this first in the theater shortly after its' August 1993 release. I saw it again on fresh video release about seven months later,and sometime later on a medium I don't immediately recall. EAch time I am struck by the fact that,despite my(And anybody's,really)ability to practically recite,not only the plot but the sequence of events,even some of the exact lines spoken by each character,this film just plain simply DOES NOT lose its potency,interest,energy or even suspense. Credit goes to the actors--not only HArrison Ford and Tommy Lee JOnes as pursued and pursuer,but also JOnes' posse of fellow feds(Joe PAntoliano,Tom Wood,Daniel Roebuck among them)and the shady side characters such as Dr.Kimble's colleague(Jeroen Krabbe)or the one-armed man himself(hulking,brooding Andreas KAtsulas)--for building the interest through intelligence and uncanny acting AND reacting. Director Andrew DAvis,a whiz at action films,is able to camera shoot and plan practically every element of this film to exquisite perfection! David Twohy's script is parts construction and ad-lib(if you see the extras on the DVD,you'll know what I mean),and the ability for Ford and some minor players,such as Ron DEan and Joe Katsulas as the arresting and highly suspicious(!)detectives,to be able to create a great sense of conflict and reaction to add tension.I just caught this again as a free rental,and to me there's really no price on it. I'd buy it,I'd see it on the tele. Maybe you all know the story of the beleaguered and ultimately innocent Dr.Richard Kimble and his chief,cunning, "Les Miserables"-like law enforcement pursuer Philip/Samuel Gerard,but that still shouldn't hinder one from seeing and--for me,anyway--enjoying this excellent piece of big budget film-making(a somewhat rare commodity it seems anymore)again and again.

Review title: One of the most intelligent action movies
Review_body:
In the opening scenes of "The fugitive" the pace of the events is extremely fast. A woman is murdered, her husband is suspect because she had a large life insurance policy and before we know it her husband is sentenced to death. This makes the opening not very plausible, but it sets the scene for a movie that is tense from that moment on towards the very end. It often happens in action movies that either the opening is unlikely, but once you have accepted that, the story keeps rolling ("The Pelican brief", 1993, Alan J. Pakula). Another pitfall is that the main character slips off into diffuculties in a way very imaginable, but the director feels obliged to put in an overdosis of action towards the end ("The firm", 1993, Sydney Pollack). "The fugitive" is of the first kind, but the director is so wise to keep the improbable opening sequence as short as possible.I read somewhere that main character Dr Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford) is caught in a "Kafkaësk" situation. In my opinion that is not true. Everybody knows that Dr Kimble is innocent (except the police and the judge), but the murder charge agianst him is chrystal clear. This is the way Alfred Hitchcock used to make films, not the way Franz Kafka used to write books. See for example "The trial" (1962, Orson Welles) in which Josef K has no idea of what he is accused.After the death sentence the movie consists of three parts. The first is the escape and staying out of the hands of the police. This is the most spectacular part of the film. Dr Kimble and some fellow inmates escape during the transport to death row in what is one of the most stunning scenes I have ever seen. Also the famous scene in the drainage tunnel is from this part of the film. In the second part Dr Kimble starts his investigations to find the real murderer of his wife and in the third part the leader of the police hunt (Deputy Marshal Samuel Gerard played by Tommy Lee Jones) gets doubts about the guilt of Kimble.The transision from part two to three is subtle and very interesting. Gerard never explicitely states he is starting to doubt the guilt of Kimble, but you can sense it from his actions. His hunt becomes less intense, as if he is willing to allow Kimble some more time to prove his innocence. Apart from that Gerard has never said that he thought Kimble was guilty. A crucial dialogue in the drainage tunnel goes like this:Dr. Richard Kimble: I didn't kill my wife!
Deputy Marshal Samuel Gerard: I don't care!Gerard sees it as his job to catch Kimble and that is what he is going to do. It is as simple as that! At least in part 1 of the film.

Review title: An Action Movie Of The Highest Calibre
Review_body: This exhilarating action thriller is full of plot twists, suspense and excitement from start to finish but what distinguishes it from other movies of the same genre is its two main characters who are both good guys who, through extraordinary circumstances, become adversaries. Both men are very smart and incredibly determined and it's their efforts to outwit each other that grips the audience so strongly and creates a dual which is riveting to watch.The story of a man who's unjustly accused of a crime he didn't commit and then has to go in search of the real culprit to prove his innocence (whilst also being pursued by the police) is, of course, a set up for the classic double chase plot which inevitably puts the accused in numerous dangerous situations and under constant pressure because of the ever present threat of capture.In "The Fugitive" Dr Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford), is a Chicago surgeon who's sentenced to death for the brutal murder of his wife. Whilst he and some other prisoners are being transported by bus to the Illinois State Penitentiary, an attempted escape by one of the other prisoners leads to the driver losing control of the vehicle and swerving off the road and into the path of an on-coming train. The resulting collision provides Kimble with the opportunity to make a run for it. After making his escape, this man who has nothing to lose decides to track down the one-armed man who he knows was his wife's real murderer.Deputy U.S. Marshall Samuel Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones), is the man whose job it is to hunt down the escaped convicts and after the bus crash, he quickly arrives on the scene and takes charge of the situation. His dogged pursuit of Kimble is relentless but surprisingly as the chase goes on, what he discovers leads him to suspect that his prey may not be guilty and what he learns about Kimble inspires a certain amount of respect although this never, even for a second, deters him from his single-minded commitment to carrying out his task to its conclusion."The Fugitive" is skilfully directed by Andrew Davis and the pace of the action is absolutely breathtaking. The sequence early on in the film during which the audience sees the events that led to Kimble's arrest is a marvellous example of this and the momentum is then maintained as there are numerous situations where Kimble has narrow escapes from being caught and the consistent level of tension just seems to escalate as Gerard is regularly only one step behind his quarry.The action set pieces are all brilliantly staged but the bus / train crash is easily the most impressive with further excitement being added when Kimble makes his incredible last minute leap to escape from danger. The screenplay is also excellent and includes some enjoyable moments of humour which provide an effective counterpoint to the suspense which features strongly throughout.Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are thoroughly convincing in their roles and show so much more of what they're thinking and feeling by their expressions and body language than they do through what they say. Ford's fear and the strain he's under, is constantly evident in his face and Jones, whose character is a consummate professional who's adopted a persona which works well for him in the context of his job, subtly shows that below his aggressive surface resides a rather warmer and more understanding man.It's easy to see why this movie was such a box office success as it scores highly on every level and combines visceral excitement so perfectly with intelligence and humour.

Review title: Pure action and Tommy Lee Jones make this an unforgettable masterpiece
Review_body: Arnold and Sly are great action heroes.  Their characters are always larger than life.  Rambo and Rocky are household names and The Terminator and films like Commando are great partly because of Arnold's physical presence.  But as good as they are, I don't think they can hold a candle to Harrison Ford. Sure he is in great shape, but have you ever seen an actor take average guys and make them so real that you want to know them?  Take your pick, Han Solo, Indy and even his character in Six Days and Seven Nights was an adventurer. Add Richard Kimble to that list.  As Kimble, Ford is perfect.  He is the wronged man that has to avenge his wife's death and clear his name at the same time.  He is so great in this film and I'm sure that's why so many people went to see this film at first.  But I think what kept them coming back was Tommy Lee Jones.  We'll get to him in a minute.Andrew Davis proved here that he is one of the best action directors in the business today.  Along with Under Siege, he showed us that he is an efficient artist that knows how to keep the action flowing.  He never seems to let up with his relentless pursuit of the perfect scene.  But since the film did so well and everyone pretty much knows what it is about, let's talk about the true strength of the film, and that would be Tommy Lee Jones." I don't bargain."  " Well that's odd!"His portrayal of Samuel Girard is an exercise in how to make the audience relate and understand a character.  He starts off as a manic perfectionist. He is obsessed with capturing Kimble and that is all that matters.  But as the film proceeds, you can sense his unease, his wonder and his ethos. You can tell by a simple expression that he is beginning to solve a crime and not just chase a criminal.  And the turning point to me was his simple scene where he says " You know Devlin and McGregor made 4 and one half billion dollars last year?  That company's a monster. "  It is all in his face. He knows that Ford is innocent but he still has a job to do.  It is Jones that makes this film so much fun.  And I didn't think that there would be a more worthy recipient of best supporting actor in '93 than Kilmer in Tombstone, but Jones' work here was well deserving of his Oscar.The Fugitive belongs on every top 100 list and if the AFI wasn't so enthralled with older movies, they would see that films like this are more worthy than some of the mediocrity that graces their findings.  This is an incredible film.

Review title: A strong TV to film adaptation with great performances by Ford and Jones that's also a excellent thriller in its own right.
Review_body: When vascular surgeon Dr. Richard Kimble's (Harrison Ford) wife Helen (Sela Ward) is murdered by a one armed intruder, Kimble is wrongly convicted and sentenced to death. When a group of prisoners stage an escape attempt on Kimble's prison transport that results in the transport crashing, Kimble rescues one of the guards and eventually goes on the run. Now hunted by the tenacious and driven Deputy U. S. Marshal Sam Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones) and his team, Kimble must evade capture while finding his wife's true killer.Running from 1963 to 1967, the Quinn Martin produced The Fugitive became a massive success during it's original run at one point being the 5th highest watched TV show and garnering many Emmy nominations. The show of a man who had to be on the move because of some force or organization chasing him helped shape an entire subgenre of TV with the likes of shows such as Kung Fu, The A-Team, The Incredible Hulk, and The Pretender utilizing similar formats to tell ongoing episodic television. Produced during the wave of TV to film adaptations that began with The Untouchables and continued through the 90s, The Fugitive may be one of, if not, the best examples of the trend capturing the spirit of the original series while also managing to update itself to good effect with high tension, an engaging adventure/mystery, and two very solid leads that all serve to make the movie the entertaining ride it is.At it's core, The Fugitive is about a man in the wrong place at the wrong time with the odds stacked against him. Playing against his more noted rugged image, Ford's Richard Kimble is a good man who cares about people and just wants his life back after having it stolen from him. There are a number of scenes in the film where Kimble has the opportunity to run or get a head start on his pursuers but doesn't because he sees people in danger or in need of assistance and Kimble will use his medical expertise to do so. Not only does it make Richard a likable character, but does a good job paying homage to the series. And of course opposite Kimble is his pursuer in Deputy U. S. Marshal Sam Gerard for which Tommy Lee Jones won an Academy Award for his performance. The role of Sam Gerard is terrific because while Jones plays the character with authority and intensity, he also plays the part with a sense of humor making asides with his team who all bring unique personalities to the table for Gerard to bounce off of. There's also a paternal quality to the character where he cares about his team but and will do anything to protect them but not at the expense of the mission. It's a really strong performance from Jones and watching his inner struggle as he learns more about Kimble's case is some terrific work.The script by David Twohy and Jeb Stuart is fantastic with some thrilling but grounded action/adventure elements that work well in combination with the "innocent man" mystery motivating the film's progression. The Fugitive knows what makes a good mystery and works well in giving the audience answers only to lead to more questions. Even if you do happen to figure out any of the reveals ahead of time, the movie's quick pacing and clever dialogue will ensure the ride getting there will be well worth it.The Fugitive is not only a gold standard for feature film adaptations of TV shows, but also for Summer Blockbusters in general. With two top of their game leads playing off strong material that keeps up the tension to the last act, The Fugitive is both intelligent and thrilling and has lent itself to parody, homage, and imitators because it's just that good.

Review title: An all-time chase thriller with 2 enduring performances
Review_body: THE FUGITIVE is one of the very few examples where a film adaptation of a hit TV show perhaps surpasses that TV show in scope, ambition, and payoff. The classic 1960s series "THE FUGITIVE", starring the perfectly cast David Janssen as somber, falsely accused Dr. Richard Kimble, has been one-upped by this 1993 masterpiece of an action-adventure film THE FUGITIVE, starring the rugged, unique Harrison Ford in the role of Kimble. Ford has similarities to Janssen, but there are also differences. Ford is much more burly and more of an intimidating presence than Janseen was and so you couldn't see Janssen kicking someone's ass the way Ford could. But Ford definitely does excellent job of capturing the calm, meek, quiet nature that Janssen so perfectly conveyed in the series, with added touches of desperation and fear. This is important as Kimble was always designed to be a 'regular everyday Joe', one of us. We HAVE to relate to him and sympathize with him and the more cocky, brutish characters that Ford has played in the past (Han Solo, Indiana Jones, etc.) have no part in this movie. I just hate that Ford didn't get a Best Actor nomination for this film as it is truly a performance deserving of one.The 2nd great performance in this already-classic film is that of Tommy Lee Jones, who truly came into his own with this movie. He won Oscar for Best Supporting Actor, but c'mon! We all know he was really the 2nd lead of this film. Jones plays Kimble's pursuer Deputy Marshal Sam Gerard (in the series it was Barry Morse playing Lt. Philip Gerard). About the only thing Jones and Morse have in common is that they are short men. That's about it! While Morse was much more calm and reserved as Gerard, Jones' Gerard is all out full-throttle, in-your-face, get-the-job-done-or-else version of the character. Full of juice throughout the entire film, Jones conveys a man obsessed with doing his job at whatever cost, but along the way, we get to see flashes of humanity and insight that makes us realize that Gerard isn't just some carbon copy blind cop. He begins to realize that maybe Kimble's assertion that he didn't kill his wife might be true. Kimble is a 'fugitive' and Gerard is fully within his right to arrest him and bring him in, whether Kimble is guilty of his convicted crime or not, but at the same time, Gerard's no-nonsense persona shines at welcome moments when he's dealing with people who are either buffoonish, deceptive, or apathetic. This is a key ingredient that makes this film work.Another brilliant aspect of this film is all the minor characters that Kimble encounters along the way, none of which have a big role, but all seem like actual people, just going about their everyday business. But none of these characters detract from the main plot of the film, thus THE FUGITIVE flows throughout.Like many great action films, the film contains some exciting scenes and set pieces (the train crash, the dam chase, the county jail chase, and the exciting climax with the one-armed man).Special mention should also go to the actors (Daniel Roebuck, L. Scott Caldwell, Tom Wood, and especially Joe Pantoliano), who play Gerard's deputies aiding him in the search for Kimble. The chemistry of this group is totally convincing and fun to watch and listen to.Andrew Davis directed this Best Picture nominee from 1993 and I would definitely rate it as one of the best films of the 1990s and one of the best action films ever!

Based as it is on the famous television series everyone knows the rather simple premise of this film. Dr. Richard Kimble is accused of murdering his wife but we know darned well that Kimble is innocent. No mystery here, the one-armed man did it. Unfortunately for the good doctor all the evidence points to himself and he is duly convicted and sentenced to death. But fortune shines on Richard Kimble as while being transported to prison the opportunity for him to escape presents itself. After a thrilling, wonderfully executed, train wreck sequence Kimble finds himself a free man. In order to remain free he will have to survive in a cold, rugged, unforgiving landscape. And he will need to evade a dogged pursuer. Enter U.S. Marshal Samuel Gerard. And away we go.After initially evading capture Kimble faces new challenges. He has to find a way to survive in the world without any money. Not an easy thing. And he has to conduct his own investigation of his wife's murder, find the real killer and prove his innocence. And he must do this while going unnoticed in his hometown of Chicago where more than a few people are looking for him. It's a simple story and there is great tension as the chase begins. Maintaining that level of tension for the over two hour running time of the film would prove to be a challenge. It's a film with an energy that somewhat wanes as we move towards the end.Perhaps the biggest problem with the film is that apparently the filmmakers thought the simple story was a little too simple for its own good. The one-armed man isn't enough, there has to be some kind of grand conspiracy and another dastardly villain. Somebody decided the compelling story of the wrongly accused man wasn't enough. In trying to explain the events leading up to the murder of Kimble's wife the film really does take an unfortunate detour and much of the tension drains out of the story. The film is at its best when Gerard is trying to track down Kimble. Tommy Lee Jones created a truly memorable character with his portrayal of Gerard. While less showy than Jones, Harrison Ford does well with his role as Kimble. Left to their own devices these two characters would have been enough to make a truly excellent film. The film was always about Kimble and Gerard, Ford and Jones. Those are the characters we care about, identify with and root for. In fact Jones is so good, so compelling, that you're almost rooting for his character to succeed as much as you are for the plainly innocent Kimble. But instead of leaving well enough alone with these two men in the end the film devolves into a big conspiracy saga that rather disappoints. As the final act plays out there's too much going on, keeping it simple would have worked much better. The end result is a good film but one which with a more sharply focused story probably could have been something much greater.

My Take: Terrific performances and thrilling sequences come together as a satisfying thriller. I enjoyed "The Fugitive" when I watched it on TV. It has just the right elements for a total action flick. Great performances, excellent escapist plot, strong direction and daredevil cliffhangers. The film is a big-screen reworking of the beloved TV series.Harrison Ford plays Dr. Richard Kimble, the man at run from the law in order to pursue the one-armed man who murdered his wife. Tommy Lee Jones is deputy Samuel Gerard, who will not stop until he find Kimble. The film really follows the events from the original series, all rolled into one thrilling movie. Lee Jones is one of the main highlights in the film, in his Oscar-winning performance as Gerard. Ford was great too, and really deserves an Oscar. Director Andrew Davis deserves the credit for his edgy and gritty direction."The Fugitive" is a great action film. One, wherein every minute is surrounded by suspense and non-stop action. Don't miss it.Rating: **** out of 5.

I don't care what any of the critics say about Harrison Ford; I love his work (I like Michael Douglas, too, so there must be something wrong with me) and he is at his best in this slick, taut, fast-paced, intriguing & suspenseful action story, which has what it takes to keep you involved - a fine script, great interaction between 2 leads (Jones & Ford), and direction which never allows the movie to lag. You don't need explosions and car crashes when you have those.But this movie does gives you one big crash, and because just one they evidently decided it had better be big. The bus crash / train wreck is alone worth seeing the movie for. ("How do they DO that?" asked my wife. "Once", I replied)Escapist adventure fare that is not mindless.

After a traffic collision convicted murderer Dr Richard Kimble (Ford) tries to clear his name whist Samuel Gerard (Jones) attempts to track him down.This Andrew Davis picture brings together a slick plot flowing with action and intrigue and with Tommy Lee Jones and Harrison Ford on perfect form this is the perfect remedy to an absent action injury.With James Bond being "reborn" these last few years and The Bourne trilogy racking up plaudits from everywhere it seems we have reinvented the term of thriller in a genre that is often scrutinized for its lack of realism in context.What makes the Fugitive tick? For starters this is a fun adrenaline soaking thriller that needs minimal explanation to get the blood pumping. From waterfall jumps to train crashes this has enough to fulfil the viewer's requirements.There is an array of credited actors who have broken barriers in their lifetimes previous to this Oscar winner. Tommy Lee Jones (winner of best supporting actor) has of course starred in plenty of action thrillers. Under Siege, No country for old men and possibly Men in Black he knows how to tackle the action. Having just reviewed the Oscars from 15 years ago I must confess to having liked John Malkovich's protagonist in the Wolfgang Peterson thriller In The Line of Fire plenty more. The swagger and evilness of Booth was elaborate, eccentric and malicious with a delicious cunning that made his character seem approachable but undeniably sick and evil. Jones nevertheless presents a character with baggage but does not convey it and with an intelligent appreciation of law and crime he sets the benchmark to the law breaking citizens of America.Ford establishes himself as mystery man in the early stages where we believe he could be good or evil and when the plot momentarily loses its balance we know the truth of his innocence.This narrative of a man needing to escape and prove his name as innocent is reflective of numerous other thrillers there's no question. Bearing in mind this concept can become tedious when seeing repetitive viewings of various thrillers it is significant to recognize this was one of the early films that brought this technique to the attention of the critiques and various other filmmakers. It is a stunning concept that adds tension and mystery from every aspect.The scene setting is wonderfully exuberant. The forest setting generates the feeling of isolation exquisitely whilst the montages of the flashbacks fittingly reflect this isolation and gives the central character development and contemplation.There are lapses in the action with an overhaul in dialogue and the Bourne series has shown the meaning of thriller but this is undoubtedly fast and fun mystery.

A murdered wife. A one-armed man. An obsessed detective. The chase begins. Harrison Ford is The Fugitive. Are you hooked yet? I don't know about you but this is enough to get my attention. The tagline pretty much sums up all the important aspects of The Fugitive. Harrison Ford plays Dr. Richard Kimble who comes home one night to find his wife murdered. He is accused of committing the crime and, despite pleading innocent and telling everyone it was a mysterious one armed man who killed her, he is sentenced to death. Kimble escapes his detainment and begins a relentless search for his wife's true killer. All the while he is being chased by Detective Samuel Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones), only making his search all the more difficult.The Fugitive is a cool film. That's really all I can say. It has got a lot of great aspects to it that keep you interested and very entertained. If you are into thrilling mysteries with plenty of enticing action then this is a great movie for you. The movie mostly plays out with the kind of tone you would expect, throwing in a few tricks along the way that makes for a very entertaining story. This film never lost my interest but it never spiked it. I was amused by the film the whole way through and enjoyed it enough to not regret watching it at all. It boasts some great set pieces and fun chase sequences through these busy urban sets. The film has a lot of characters but the only two that really draw you in are Kimble and Gerard. The two are played excellently by Ford and Jones respectively.The best way to describe The Fugitive would be high quality escapist entertainment. This is simply one of those movies you take at face value. There isn't a whole lot to take out of this film, and you really just have to watch it for a good time. It pretty much succeeds in that area. I wasn't blown away by this film but I wasn't bored or irritated by it either. It doesn't have any glaring issues that bothered me other than the occasional silly line or ridiculous moment that makes you go, "yeah right." Overall it isn't a movie that is very aesthetically impressive, but it does have its moments. This isn't one of those films that you can bash, but rather just accept it for the fun use of two hours of your life that it is.The Fugitive is a lot of fun and it's easy to enjoy. It doesn't require a significant amount of brainpower but it isn't a braindead schlock of a film either. When you look at the action thriller genre, The Fugitive stands as the genre done just right. There isn't too much or too little with this film, it's simply just a good ole film that is worth the watch.

Slick, suspenseful update of the TV series and simply a well made entry in the innocent man on the run genre has Ford as the doctor framed for murdering his wife and Jones (in the role that made him a star again) as the federal marshal who doggedly pursues him, even though there's nothing personal in it for him.Jones reprised his character for the sequel, "US Marshals", which had Wesley Snipes as a marine in the Ford part.Harrison Ford delivers his usual strong performance as the wrongly convicted doctor who has to find "the one armed man" and stay one step ahead of the man chasing him. It's easy to see why Ford actually had a post-Star Wars career: he can be funny, he can be serious, he can be menacing in a heroic way, and he's simply very good at playing regular guys who aren't exactly larger than life but he makes you invest yourself in them.Tommy Lee Jones is memorable as the federal marshal chasing Ford, full of dry, dead pan humor that makes him menacing and yet not inhuman at the same time. He manages to be both an antagonist figure and a heroic one. That's hard to do."I didn't kill my wife!" - Harrison"I don't CARE!" - Tom

Review title: The Fugitive is one of the most thoroughly entertaining films ever to careen through the action genre.
Review_body: The Fugitive turns out to be a smashing success, a juggernaut of an action-adventure saga that owes nothing to the past. Accused of his wife's murder, a doctor (Harrison Ford) goes on the run, hunting down the real killer while a cop (Tommy Lee Jones) pursues him.The original TV series, starring David Janssen, ran from 1963 to 1967. Here it is updated into an expansive action-adventure film, powered - even through its less coherent stretches - by lead performances of an old-school solidity and rigour. For his performance Jones won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor. The Fugitive was one of the few movies associated with a television series to be nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture.

Review title: A classic! The Best Harrison Ford's action flick. An Andrew Davis masterpiece!
Review_body: The Fugitive (1993) is a classic action thriller flick from Andrew Davis and Harrison Ford. It is my favorite all time classic action film from Harrison ford and Andrew Davis, that I love to death! Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones, gave their best performances on screen, I have ever seen. No wonder the score is 7.8 on IMDb, because it is a classic and I absolutely love it. I grew up, with this film and it is my childhood favorite movie. Back in 1993 this film was a hit, I remember seeing the trailer on TV as a kid, this movie was also in the theater. This is third time that Tommy Lee Jones and Ron Dean worked together with the director Andrew Davis. Tommy Lee Jones previous worked on a movies The Package and Under Siege, until he got cast in this film. Being the biggest Harrison Ford fan, I must say this is my favorite film of his. Watching him last year on YouTube on Jimmy Kimmel Live show, Harrison specifically requested Jimmy not to ask him anything about Star Wars. I don't know what happened with him on Star Wars movies and I don't care! I was never fan of Star Wars and I never will be! I was more an Indiana Jones fan and still I am. So my favorite Harrison ford Films will always be: Indiana Jones Trilogy, this one (The Fugitive), Clear and Present Danger and Patriot Games. Those are the films I grew up with it.Plot: Dr. Richard Kimble, unjustly accused of murdering his wife, must find the real killer while being the target of a nationwide manhunt. I know that this movie is based on original TV series from the 60's with David Janssen and it was also based on a doctor who was accused of murdering his wife, which he didn't, I watched the TV movie. I love this film to death, Andrew Davis Sensational directed the film, no shaky cam and no CGI in the movie. The special effects were great, the acting performance from the cast was perfect and the chase sequences were incredible. The film is entertained from the beginning till end. I love the music score by James Newton Howard in the film, the plot and the story is brilliant. About the character Dr. Richard Kimble, this character has a heart. I love how Richard (Harrison Ford) was pretending to be a janitor the same time, while he was looking in the prosthetic limb area for patient information matching the description of the one-armed man. The best scene and favorite of mine is a scene, when a doctor (Julianne Moore) asks Kimble to take down a boy down the stairs in the operation room, who has a chest broken and Kimble doesn't obey her, he sees the record and he writes a description, he talks to the boy and he put him in the right surgery floor and saves the young boy's life. That scene touches my heart every time, I see it. This film has a heart, it does show that Kimble is not only innocent, but he is a good hearted person, that he was convicted wrongfully, for the crime he did not commit. That is why I love this movie. I also love Tommy Lee Jones' character Deputy U.S. Marshal Samuel Gerard who later starts to believing that the man is innocent, but he has to do the job by bringing him back to hand of the law. I love his line "I...don't...bargain." About the cast: Beside Harrison Ford which I love him that he did an outstanding, believing acting and the best performance. Tommy Lee Jones as Deputy U.S. Marshal Samuel Gerard was outstanding which I loved him in this movie. Joe Pantoliano as Deputy U.S. Marshal Cosmo Renfro was terrific, recently I just watched him in Bad Boys II and I seriously love his voice. Julianne Moore as Dr. Anne Eastman has only two scenes and made only a cameo scene in this film, which she was awesome! later she played the main role in my favorite all time adventure flick The Lost World: Jurassic Park (1997). Andreas Katsulas as Fredrick Sykes was fantastic and he was awesome villain I love him in this film. Jeroen Krabbé as Dr. Charles Nichols was incredible as a doctor and the villain I love him. The last actress I want to mention in this movie is L. Scott Caldwell as Deputy U.S. Marshal Erin Poole she was also awesome. I know she had a small role in here, I am really wondering why she didn't return in the sequel U.S. Marshals (1998). Overall: I love this movie to death, it is my childhood movie that I have grew up with it and it is my Harrison Ford and Andrew Davis favorite film of all time I love it! Review title: Watch out... You may just gnaw your fingers off.
Review_body: An all-time classic chase thriller with an equally compelling character study, The Fugitive ranks as one of the best examples of it's genre around. As dogged detective Tommy Lee Jones hunts his prey (an innocent doctor, played by Harrison Ford) through hospitals, street parades, and even the Hoover Dam, the interaction between the two and the amount of near misses will have you falling off the edge of your seat. And there is also Ford's quest to prove his inculpability in the murder of his wife... Jones's bonding with his hand-picked investigation team... Exactly how much can you squeeze into a two hour long feature?!My favourite aspect of the production isn't the brilliantly directed scenes of pursuit, or the slow unveiling of who WAS responsible for the tragic crime, or even Harrison Ford as the wronged man who nevertheless stops to help others even while on the run (Thus engaging him perfectly with the audience's sympathies). Nope, that would be Tommy Lee Jones as the bombastic police office in charge of the capture... He is never short of something to say... Doesn't take crap from anyone... And (most of all), the small looks in his eyes as the evidence mounts that Ford may not be the one responsible for his spouse's demise after all. He turns from the man trying to get Ford at all costs... To the only one willing to protect him in the heated climax...A great character, brought to life by a great actor. Someone give that chap an Oscar... Whoops, he received one. WOWEE Life Is Good. :) 8/10

Review title: Ford and Jones in top form.
Review_body: Now,I am not a big fan of the idea of the small screen to the big screen,and being a fan of the original television series with David Janssen and Barry Morse made me a skeptic at the beginning,but I must say I was more than pleasantly surprised with the big screen version of The Fugitive.Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones make an excellent pairing and both are in top form here.Yes,the story has been reworked somewhat,and a few names changed,but this film does it's job splendidly.In my own humble opinion,this action film is second only to Terminator 2:Judgment Day as tops for the decade of the nineties.My wife and I visited the area in North Carolina recently where the train wreck sequence was filmed and the train is very much still there and quite the tourist attraction.If you are a fan of the old series,and have boycotted this film because you are afraid it will disappoint you,my advice to you would be not to rob yourself of the pleasure of this great film any further.You may just wind up with a whole new passion for this story.Thumbs up!

Review title: 3 Days of the Condor meets Braveheart
Review_body: Here's Davis' second most interesting film, perhaps the most successful TV-quality movie ever made.  The biggest problem is that Davis is too pedestrian in his methods and never adopts a useful style.  Richard Donner and Spielberg have covered multiple topics in their careers, but have also maintained a sense of style.  Davis takes everything at face value.Here Ford is called upon to do something other than quip Lucas-inspired dialog, something he also failed at with Witness.  Pantoliano does his usual cross-Buscemi routine.  Jones does his 'Under Siege' bit all over again.Simply put, here's as dramatic as Davis and his cohorts can get.Final Analysis = = Midrange Material

Review title: Exciting game of cat and mouse with an underwhelming final act
Review_body: Thoroughly entertaining non-stop drama featuring Harrison Ford at his sombre best. A bit corny round the edges but stands out among the vast array of nineties action movies. Ending is scrappy and prolonged, certainly didn't leave me as surprised or satisfied as it might have done.

Review title: One of the best chase movies ever
Review_body: Although the outcome is never in doubt, The Fugitive is one of the best "chase" movies ever, successfully maintaining the suspense from first to last. Tommy Lee Jones won an Oscar as best supporting actor for this film but it is also among Harrison Ford's best performances. Based loosely on a celebrated murder which would have been even more famous if CNN and Fox had been pursuing the story, The Fugitive records Harrison's pursuit by Jones as a U.S. Marshall attempting to capture the doctor accused of killing his wife, while Harrison tries to find the actual killer with Jones never very far behind. There was a TV series before the movie -- and it was pretty good. But the movie is better. Of its type, The Fugitive is one of the best, though it trails both North by Northwest (the Cary Grant vehicle) and the Open Window. Very Hitchcock-ian, which is a high compliment for those who did not see Hitchcock at his peak.

This movie, filled with action, is one of the best in its genre. Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones both deliver solid performances. Don't worry if you have not followed the hit tv-series, you can still enjoy this movie. I must admit though that the second time I saw it, I gave it a lower note. But still, it's good for a 8.
Mystery and deceit with a doctor found guilty of murdering his wife is the basis of a real thriller from 1993. No more needs to be said. The movie is available again, so don't miss it!

Like a lot of Hitchcock films, The Fugitive centers on the premise of a wrongfully accused man who must clear his name. The cat and mouse game between him and his nemesis makes for exhilarating entertainment. The entire exercise seems plausible. Dr. Kimble goes about his task in a logical and efficient manner and U.S. Marshall Gerard chases him with a frenzied zeal. The close calls are exciting. Though the stunts are spectacular, especially the famous plunge from the drain and the leap from the onrushing train, thankfully they do not overshadow the human drama. A top notch thriller, 9/10.

Review title: Great acting and scene by scene suspense
Review_body: Finally getting around to writing a review of this movie after so long, I am glad to report that I still like this great action movie and particularly, the rivalry between two actors from the 1970's generation -- Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones. Without the two actors, the movie would have been largely forgotten but the two antagonists are in full flight and in their prime. (Maybe a few years past.) The movie features one long chase with police only a step behind as prison escapee Dr. Richard Kimble tries to outwit and out-run Samuel Gerard, federal Marshall. Kimble races across Illinois to Chicago from highway to subway to hospitals and flophouses with a pause at the St. Patricks's Day Parade. Viewers are treated to some exciting scenes as Kimble successfully dodges police as he changes his appearance by shaving his beard, changing from day clothes to uniform and back again. He seeks out friends whose help he needs to establish his innocence. In the end, the two men meet in the back seat of a car, where they share a mutual respect, well earned by both, after a lengthy combat. Credit to director Andrew Davis for great scene by scene suspense.

Review title: Thrills and Excitement from start to finish
Review_body: Obviously in a film of this type, its clear "he didn't do it", but clearing his name is what the film is all about, the cops think hes guilty and to be fair they seem to be the dumbest film cops of all time!. The appearance of Tommy Lee Jones definitely adds to the quality of Andrew Davis direction as he unfolds everything to the final conclusion. catch this one, well worth the time and effort

Review title: Ford runs this explosive facelift of the old TV series.
Review_body: Not so many TV-to-film transfers can live up to greatness, but THE FUGITIVE can prove that enhancing an original plotline with a right edge can turn into a super movie. The added suspense lives up to calling this just another mega-thriller that differs the original black-and-white series. Both Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are fully demanding in giving this the raw energy a simple cat-and-mouse story needs. For interesting terminology, the leading characters are on opposite sides of their personalities, with "good" convict Kimble evading the so-called "villainous" U.S. Marshal who is out to capture him. Ford uses the old INDIANA JONES trick in a couple of the riskiest stunts performed on film, but he keeps the action moving. One drawback is that you're now beginning to notice his recent characters a bit more worrisome than heroic, but Ford gets the job done as usual. Much of THE FUGITIVE displays continuous action and suspense until the rousing climax. Look for a hospital nurse that appears in the form of Julianne Moore. This will most likely end up as one of the Top 10 action thrillers of the decade before the 90s is through.

Review title: An Innocent Man On The Run
Review_body: Of all the old TV shows that have become big-screen movies, THE FUGITIVE must be one of the very few that actually works.  A transfer to the big screen of a fine TV series that starred the late David Janssen and ran on ABC-TV from 1963 to 1967, THE FUGITIVE had all the earmarks of a great film, and it does not disappoint.Taking over for Janssen, Harrison Ford stars as Dr. Richard Kimble, a prominent Chicago surgeon who is convicted for the brutal slaying of his wife Helen (Sela Ward)--a crime he did not commit.  While on his way to meet his fate in an Illinois prison, the bus he and other prisoners are riding in suffers an accident, and is literally crushed by a freight train.  Ford manages to make it out of the wreckage and escapes into the woods.  Now, however, he not only has the whole Illinois state police and the Chicago P.D. on his trail, he also has a phalanx of U.S. marshals, led by the tenacious Sam Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones).With all the odds stacked against him, Ford constantly has to change his appearance to avoid detection while at the same time going after the one-armed man who actually killed his wife.  The result is a gripping cat-and-mouse game through the streets of the Windy City, a literal battle of wits between Ford and Jones that made for some of the best movie-making of the Nineties.Superbly directed by Andrew Davis (UNDER SIEGE; CODE OF SILENCE), THE FUGITIVE is not only a brilliant big-screen translation of a fine TV show from the past, it also echoes a theme familiar to Alfred Hitchcock--a man on the run for a crime he never committed.  Ford is the man in that position. Jones won a well-deserved Supporting Actor Oscar for his role as Gerard, but as Jones himself readily admitted, it is Ford's portrayal of Richard Kimble that is at the heart of this great thriller.  Not nearly as violent as a lot of action films have tended to be, THE FUGITIVE is one of the finest in its genre, well worth seeing.
